Hi Klaus,

I know that it currently doesn't support JUnit trends. All that I could 
say is either customize it for JUnits with added benefits it currently has 
to offer or check in the "to-do" list of QALAB, may be this is being 
worked upon by someone in the community.

Regards,
Sachin Navinchandra Dholakia




"kp.berg" <Klaus-Peter.Berg@...> 
Sent by: junit@yahoogroups.com
01/08/2006 02:40 PM
Please respond to
junit@yahoogroups.com


To
junit@yahoogroups.com
cc

Subject
[junit] Re: Looking for a JUnit diff and trend analysis tool






Hi,

if looking at QALAB I found
"This project collects and consolidate data from several QA tools, 
like pmd, checkstyle, FindBugs and Simian and keeps track of them 
overtime."
There is nothing to read about JUnit tests and diffs... So, how do 
you 
think I can implement my requirements with this tool?

--Klaus


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kamal2222ahmed" <Kamal.Ahmed@w...> 
wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@v...> 
wrote:
> >
> > sachin.dholakia@t... wrote:
> > > Hi Klaus,
> > > 
> > > There is a tool namely QALAB which is used to pick info from 
XML
> files and 
> > > generate so called Movers and Shakers of build. You want to 
have a
> look at 
> > > it.
> > 
> > Thanks for that tip! That looks even better than the Maven 
Historical 
> > plugin that I recommended in another response.
> > 
> > > 
> > > David Saff <saff@m...> 
> > > Sent by: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > 01/05/2006 07:04 PM
> > > Please respond to
> > > junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > 
> > > 
> > > To
> > > junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > cc
> > > 
> > > Subject
> > > Re: [junit] Looking for a JUnit diff and trend analysis tool
> > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Klaus,
> > > 
> > > I wrote a hack for something like this a while ago, but it was
> optimized 
> > > for looking at failing tests over hundreds of program versions,
> parsed 
> > > from text output files.  I imagine that you could probably 
write 
> > > something to do this yourself as quickly as extracting the
> interesting 
> > > parts from my code.
> > > 
> > > Can you give a few details about what you would be looking for 
in a 
> > > trend analysis?  Thanks,
> > > 
> > >     David Saff
> > > 
> > > kp.berg wrote:
> > > 
> > > 
> > >>Hi all,
> > >>
> > >>I know, JUnit 'unit' tests should always pass ;-) But we are 
using the
> > >>JUnit framework to write integration and systemtests as well. 
So from
> > >>time to time, in this area something may go wrong. Therefore 
I'm
> > >>looking for a tool, that generates a report showing only the
> > >>differences between current and last JUnit report - which 
failing
> > >>tests were fixed, which tests stopped to pass, which tests 
were added
> > >>and which removed. Additionaly a test trend analysis should be
> > >>possible.
> > >>
> > >>I know, parsing the XML junitreport output and generating the 
info,
> > >>e.g., with the help of a database, would be possible. But is 
anyone
> > >>aware of an existing tool or open source project that can help 
in this
> > >>direction?
> >
> 
> 
> Is there such a tool for eclipse/perforce?
>
